awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Novel Tactile Online Nursing Trainer for Clinical Breast Exams
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is about a devastating medical error that affects millions of women, a breast cancer that can be felt by hand but remains unconfirmed and untreated for months or years. Known as missed, palpable breast cancer, the cause is plainly, lack of training and skill. The result is delayed diagnosis for millions of women and disease that is more extensive, painful, and costly. Poorly performed breast exams also result in unnecessarily high rates of false positive findings, which means ?detecting? disease that is not truly present. MammaCare scientists developed and standardized training and certification for nurses and physicians to perform proficient and effective breast exams. This training is taught by expert instructors who teach practitioners how to reliably detect small, suspicious breast tumors, about the size of a pea. However, this training is costly and time consuming. It cannot reach the thousands of nursing and medical students and practitioners who perform these exams. 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to reduce the toll of breast cancer by giving all nurses who examine women the skill to detect the smallest, earliest signs of the disease. To do this we created a new skill-based teaching technology using high-fidelity breast models, computers and the Internet to provide practitioners with essential breast exam skills. The training is self-administered, inexpensive, and effective. Our colleagues at the Mayo Clinic found that nursing students and nurses were much more accurate in detecting breast tumors after the training than they were before receiving it. The potential benefits of this technology for millions of women are reduced medical errors, improved breast cancer screening accuracy, and a better chance for disease-free survival.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Improved Clinical Breast Exam Screening Standards on a National Scale

?Clinical breast exams ??(CBEs) ?are ??performed annually on millions of women? to detect the early signs of breast cancer by hand. Most breast cancers can be detected by palpation although clinical exams are typically ?haphazard and are performed ?without standards of practice or measures of effectiveness. The result of such practices is delayed diagnosis, missed cancers and false positive alarms.? ?MammaCare scientists ?created a computer- guided technology that measurably improves and verifies critical breast exam skills. This new technology can sharply reduce the unacceptable level of errors that fail to detect early, palpable breast tumors and produce high rates of false positive alarms.

 

With NSF support,?? ?this? new technology was launched nationwide among twenty-four colleges of nursing and medicine. The first national group of nearly? 1,000 ??students?? have already gained the skills ?to discriminate 3mm (pea sized), ?suspicious tumors from normal breast tissue in tactually- accurate breast models??. Without standardized training and practice clinician’s confidence and competence are compromised. Unskilled exams often result in delayed detection of breast cancer, unnecessary surgeries and an elevated risk of morbidity and mortality.

 

In response to the urgent need for effective breast cancer screening standards of practice, this project provides present and future practitioners with the core breast exam competencies that, until now, were absent. ??To advance that goal, MammaCare established ??the online “Clinical Breast Exam Competency Network” (CBCN),? that is now available to every university. The network enables all clinical students regardless of university size, location or schedule to acquire the essential breast exam? competencies and skills and to enter their results into a national competency database. The data generated and uploaded by universities demonstrates that their students acquire breast exam competencies in an orderly, incremental sequence ?of ?practice exams and tutorials. ?

?This project also demonstrated the feasibility of a mass, standardized, low-cost clinical competency training platform. The development of a novel suite? of ?clinical ??education technologies that employ advanced information technology on a national scale is a recognizable contribution to clinical education. ?The? CBECN "competency" network was developed with the support of advanced information technology engineers at MammaCare, Capgemini and Qlik corporations.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2016
Modified by: Mark Goldstein
